title: Billions of dollars of debt wiped from accounts of 100,000 Aussies
text:
Billions of dollars of student debt have been wiped from the accounts of 100,000 Australians.

The Albanese government's pre-election promise to ease student loan debt passed ﻿parliament in August and has begun to roll out from today.

About three million Australians will have ﻿a total of $16 billion of all student loans, including HELP, VET, apprenticeship support loans and student startup loans.

Education Minister Jason Clare said it was the "biggest cut in student debt ever". (Nine)

The first 100,000 people will see their debt slashed from today, with another three million to follow in the next fortnight. ﻿

Australians will receive a text message or email from the Australian Tax Office when the changes are automatically applied.

Education Minister Jason Clare said it was the "biggest cut in student debt ever".

"Today, 100,000 young Australians will get the best text message ever, telling them that their debts been cut by 20 per cent," he told Weekend Today .

"On average, that means about $5500 of debt wiped off their back.

﻿"That's a lot of help for young people, out of TAFE, just out of university, maybe they're just out of home. They're certainly just getting started in life."

The 20 per cent reduction will be calculated based on what the debt amount was on June 1, before indexation was applied.

"Sydney, Australia - August 17, 2012: Students and graduates converge on a lawn before the University of New South Wales (UNSW) library on a clear winter morning." (Getty)

The legislation also raised the minimum amount people have to make to start repaying their loans from $54,435 to $67,000 and reduced the minimum repayments.

These changes are in addition to the $3 billion cut from the indexation applied to student loans earlier this year after the government switched the index rate to be whichever is lower: the wage price index or the consumer price index. ﻿

The federal government earlier this month announced it will introduce a second round of 20 per cent cuts to student loan debt, totalling another $16 billion, by June 1 next year. ﻿

"I will always fight for every young Australian to have access to a good education," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said in a statement at the time.

﻿"This will help everyone with student debt right now, whilst we work hard to deliver a better deal for every student in the years ahead."

title: Education minister calls out prestigious school over leaked document about students
text:
Education Minister Jason Clare has criticised the failure of a prestigious girls school in Brisbane, after a leaked internal document showed teachers had commented on the appearance, behaviour and personalities of children.

Year 11 students at ﻿Somerville House, a 126-year-old boarding and day school in South Brisbane, stumbled upon a spreadsheet and found teachers had made notes about them.

Parents were then asked to think of the teachers, with students blamed for sharing the document. ﻿

Somerville House is a 126-year-old school in South Brisbane. (Jorge Branco)

Exams have been pushed back a day while the school investigates.

Clare said the school has failed in this instance. ﻿

"They've failed the students, and they've failed the parents of the kids who go to that school," he told Weekend Today.

"Schools have got to collect information, but they've got to do it in a secure way, and they've also got to do it in a professional way.

"And I don't those things has happened here."

Somerville House principal Dr Sandra Hastie said students were being offered counselling and apologised for the "distress and hurt" caused.

"We recently experienced an incident whereby some students accessed some notes about themselves and their peers.

Education Minister Jason Clare said the school had failed. (Nine)

"We sincerely apologise for the distress and hurt many within the school community are experiencing. We are very disappointed by what has happened, as the nature of some of these comments fall short of our standards and values.

"As soon as we were made aware of this incident, we worked with external experts to help us investigate what has happened."

Hastie said the school's investigation was ongoing.

"We are taking this situation very seriously and student wellbeing is our priority," she said.

"We have communicated with our school community and made counselling and pastoral care services available to them. We have also opened our Employee Assistance Program to students and families to ensure they have access to support.

"We are committed to adhering to our legal obligations and we have notified the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC)."

Somerville House was established in 1899 and is a prep to year 12 girls school taking day and boarding students.﻿

Fees start at $23,000 to more than $30,000 a year. ﻿

title: 'We're real': The type of book we may never see again thanks to AI
text:
Exclusive: J﻿K Rowling does it. As did Anne Rice and Mark Twain.

You may not realise it, but Dr Seuss did it too.

The historic practice of writing under a pseudonym, pen name or nom-de-plume may be dying a slow death - thanks, in part, to the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) in publishing.

AI could be resulting in the slow death of the writer pen name. (Graphic: Polly Hanning)

READ MORE: ﻿ Professor flooded with death threats over what he wants banned from Queensland

Research by Cambridge University this week found 51 per cent of published novelists in the UK are worried AI might end up making their jobs redundant.﻿

There are already terabytes of AI slop masquerading as books being peddled on the internet﻿ – but Queensland fantasy author Darryl King isn't worried these will destroy his career.

King, who publishes his In All Jest series under the name D.E. King, told nine.com.au there could be very different consequences of ﻿ChatGPT's influence on the book industry.

"I think all authors are struggling to find ways to market themselves and to stand out now already without AI," King explained.

"It's a bit like music where as authors, we have to go and do more signings and appearances at libraries to validate we're real."

Recent studies have found﻿ book readers value the human element more than ever when it comes to fiction.

King said this has translated into book buyers wanting to know the author more intimately.

This means no fake name and no shadowy anonymous figure, instead of a real-life author headshot.

It could impact romance writers, who typically use pen names to preserve anonymity from their real-life acquaintances, the most.

Do you have a story? Contact reporter April Glover at april.glover@nine.com.au

Queensland fantasy author Darryl King said readers value authentic authors who show their face more than ever. (Supplied)

READ MORE: Why thousands of Australians are buying and selling snack vending machines

"I think it's about those in-person real events where you can see them," King explained.

"So even if I'm buying from America, I can see the events that this guy goes to in Australia and there's might be a video or a photo from it, I'm more likely to believe they're real."

The publishing industry needs to adapt to this pressure from AI, King believes.

This could mean more money being used to promote authors on social media and in-person.﻿

"Perhaps that's what the publishing platforms need to do... to validate author profiles more," King added.

At the moment, some AI paragraphs can be easy to pick out.

Take the dreaded ﻿em dash, for example, which has become an AI calling card.

King said AI has muddied the waters – he has a copy editor from the UK who has always preferred this grammar style.

"He regularly puts em dashes into my work," he laughed.

"﻿We expect that, that it's AI and it might not be.

"So how do you tell my stories more human than another story? Is it because it's got typos occasionally?"

Book authors are increasingly worried about the impact AI has on publishing, according to research. (Getty)

King also has a day job as a web developer where he ironically often uses and learns about AI.

He said e-books were already a reason why many authors can't support themselves financially on books alone.

﻿AI is probably going to make it harder, he predicts.

"I think it was already difficult. Like other industries, we get competition from external, cheaper sources," he said.

"But I think you have to weather that. You have to find things that help you stand out.

"We all hope that people will start to filter out the rubbish."

title: The world's biggest company just told everyone to chill out
text:
Concerns about an AI bubble have been simmering for at least a year and a half. Nvidia's incredibly strong earnings this past week tried to put those fears to bed. It may not have been enough.

Nvidia on Wednesday posted sales and profits up more than 60 per cent year-on-year, stronger than Wall Street had projected. CEO Jensen Huang said "sales are off the charts". And the company expects fourth quarter revenue of about $US65 billion ($100 billion), once again ahead of Wall Street's projections.

Nvidia executives said these results, along with growth from other major AI players and the billions being poured into AI infrastructure, indicate that fears of an AI bubble are overblown.

READ MORE: Education minister calls out prestigious school over leaked document about students

Jensen Huang, NVIDIA founder and CEO, at a Q&A session during the APEC CEO summit in Gyeongju, South Korea. (Getty)

"There's been a lot of talk about an AI bubble," Huang said on a call with analysts on Wednesday. "From our vantage point, we see something very different."

Some Wall Street analysts agree. But the wider market is not yet convinced: After briefly ticking up on Thursday morning following Nvidia's report, the chipmaker's shares (NVDA) dipped back into the red. They closed Friday down 1 per cent, although the stock remains up 29 per cent from the start of this year.

In other words, Nvidia answered a lot of questions about where the industry stands right now, but it may take more to shift the overall AI narrative.

Not to burst your bubble

Nvidia CFO Colette Kress said the company anticipates $US3 trillion ($4.65 trillion) to $US4 trillion ($6.2 trillion) in annual AI infrastructure spending by the end of the decade, adding that demand "continues to exceed our expectations". Already, tech giants are expected to pour $US400 billion into AI-related capital expenditures this year, to meet what they say is growing demand for AI and cloud services but also to avoid falling behind industry rivals.

Nvidia has every reason to try to reassure investors — expectations for the company are sky-high after nearly two years of astronomical growth. And many look to the chipmaker as a bellwether for the overall tech industry.

Even as Silicon Valley tries to figure out the business model for generative AI, Nvidia has a big role to fill in the existing tech services people use every day, Huang said. That could help insulate Nvidia even if returns from new AI applications are smaller than expected or take longer to arrive than planned.

US President Donald Trump speaks with Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Elon Musk, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and others at the Saudi Investment Forum. (AP)

"The world has a massive investment in non-AI software, from data processing to science and engineering simulations, representing hundreds of billions of dollars in cloud computing spend each year." Much of the infrastructure powering that software has transitioned from running on older CPU chips to Nvidia's GPUs, the chips known for running AI tools, Huang said.

Kress also took the unusual step of ticking through highlights from the chipmaker's partners' recent financial reports. At Meta, for example, AI recommendation systems are leading to "more time spent on apps such as Facebook and Threads". Anthropic recently noted it expects to earn $US7 billion in annual revenue this year. And Salesforce's engineering team is 30 per cent more efficient now that it's using AI for coding, she said, ﻿among a long list of corporate customers she rattled off.

Nvidia isn't the only one arguing that AI bubble concerns may be exaggerated.

"The pure Nvidia numbers/guidance and strategic vision shows the AI Revolution is NOT a Bubble…instead its Year 3 of a 10-year build out of this 4th Industrial Revolution in our view," Wedbush tech analyst Dan Ives said in emailed commentary.

King Charles III presents the 2025 Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering to Jensen Huang. (Getty)

Brian Colello, senior equity analyst at investment research company Morningstar, said he doesn't "see many signs to suggest that 2026 will be a weak year for Nvidia in any way" and sees the bubble fears weighing on the company's stock as a "buying opportunity".

Fears remain

But despite those strong results, it appears the stock market may not be ready to relax just yet.

Questions remain about whether tech firms will maintain their massive spending on AI infrastructure, especially as Nvidia has invested in key, unprofitable customers such as OpenAI and Anthropic. OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar also raised alarms earlier this month when she suggested that the government should backstop the debt tech companies are incurring to build AI infrastructure. Some took her comments as a sign OpenAI may struggle to afford its commitments, although the company later tried to walk back the statement.

And while Nvidia likely has enough customers even if a bubble burst causes some casualties among AI firms, investors may still be worried about what a downturn or even a slowdown could mean for the larger market.

"There's been a lot of talk about an AI bubble," Huang said on a call with analysts on Wednesday. "From our vantage point, we see something very different." (Getty)

Daniel Morgan, senior portfolio manager at Synovus Trust Company, said questions about the sustainability of Big Tech's infrastructure spending spree and Nvidia's circular funding deals were not "put to rest" with its latest report. Instead, they may just be "punted" to the next quarter.

title: Michael got a retail job when his career plans fizzled. Now he's Bunnings' top boss
text:
Exclusive: In this nine.com.au series, we'll be talking to some of Australia's smartest and sharpest ﻿entrepreneurs, founders and CEOs to find out what makes them tick - and what advice they'd have for anyone starting out.

﻿Bunnings managing director Michael Schneider originally wanted to be a marine biologist, but the university fees were too high and a scholarship was out of reach.

Then he considered being a school teacher﻿ but that didn't suit him either, so he picked up a job in retail – and pretty much never looked back.

Now he's the top boss at one of Australia's most popular brands, with Bunnings raking in $18.97 billion in revenue in 2024﻿ alone.

These are his secrets to success.﻿

Michael Schneider originally wanted to be a marine biologist - now he's ﻿Bunnings' managing director. (Supplied)

How do you start the day to set yourself up for success?

Retailers tend to be morning people - trading performance, inventory availability and the like tend to form our habits early.

When I'm travelling, early starts are also good for exploring a city or taking in some exercise.

At home, it varies depending on the day.

Sometimes an early workout is great and occasionally a bit more sleep before coffee and a light breakfast can work a treat.

What are three daily habits you always stick to?

Every day can look different for me, whether it's heading out to stores to hear from our team or looking at an exciting new product to roll out for our customers.

No matter what I'm doing, three daily habits I stick to are:

Keep moving - avoid sitting, walking meetings are a great way to stay present and keep active. Get back to people quickly - it's polite, professional and keeps you engaged with team, customers and suppliers. Find time for a laugh - life is short, make every day count.

READ MORE: Influencer turned business owner reveals mistake jobseekers keep making

Bunnings raked in $18.97 billion in revenue in 2024﻿ alone. (Domain)

Lots of Aussies are looking for a career change. What small action can help them get ahead of other candidates?

I'm someone who has made many pivots over the course of my career.

From starting on the shop floor at Target, to studying teaching, working in financial services and then finding my way back to retail, each role has helped shape me as a teammate and leader.

My best career advice would be to take every opportunity to learn and grow, even if it means stepping outside of your comfort zone.

Be proactive in asking questions, seeking feedback and don't be afraid to put your hand up for new roles or projects.

Sometimes just being curious and taking the smallest step can lead to the biggest change.

What financial myth did you previously believe that you wish you never bought into?

For many of us starting out in our careers, there's the idea that financial success is about climbing the ladder quickly.

Over time, I've learned that resilience and consistency matter more.

Don't buy into the myth that there's a shortcut; steady progress and staying true to your values are what really counts.

Surprise entrant to top 10 most trusted brands in Australia View Gallery

What do you wish you could tell your 20-year-old self?

I'd tell myself to not worry too much about the future as it will all work out.

Every experience, good and bad, shapes who you become as a leader.

Be open to new opportunities and ideas, and build strong relationships and trust with others which will serve you well throughout your career.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: How migrant and overseas Christians are helping keep Australian churches alive
text:
An Anglican Church bishop in Queensland's north says that his 11 Pacific Islander ministers, serving the region's parishes, is saving those parishes from collapse.

"Together they make up half of my full-time workforce in the diocese," Bishop Keith Joseph said.

Census data shows the number of Australians who identify as Christian has halved from 86 per cent in 1971 to 44 per cent in 2021.

But the decrease has been tempered by Christian migrants from Asia, Africa, the Middle East and the Pacific.

Priests like Jeffery Akoai (centre) and Pasifika brothers make up half the full-time workforce of their Anglican diocese. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Bishop Joseph said priests and brothers have been recruited from the Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea and Vanuatu to fill service gaps in regional towns, Aboriginal communities and the Torres Strait.

"All that would go if we didn't have them," he said.

The north Queensland diocese is also in financial trouble because of the compensation owed to victims of historic abuse.

Christian Pacific Islanders attend a monthly Melanesian service where celebrating culture is part of their worship. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Keeping the parishes going also involves vital volunteer work including running op-shops, providing chaplaincy to aged care homes and hospitals, and pastoral care to seasonal workers.

"You're looking at each parish providing between $200,000 to a million dollars of volunteer labour into their communities each year," Bishop Joseph said.

" If [Pasifika priests] aren't the backbone of the diocese, they are certainly very important. "

The Pasifika priests are so valued by the community that a migration pathway was set up between the diocese, the Church of Melanesia and the Department of Home Affairs, the bishop said.

One priest recruited from the Solomon Islands under the agreement is Reverend Jeffrey Akoai who serves St Paul's Anglican Church at Proserpine in the Whitsundays.

Jeffery Akoai was recruited from the Solomon Islands three years ago to sustain parishes in north Queensland. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Besides regular masses he also leads a monthly Melanesian service for the region's many seasonal workers, helping to maintain social cohesion.

On Saturdays they also run a bible study for the workers which helps keep them from spending time at bars and instead saving money for their families back home.

"It's like we're creating a home, a safe space away from home, that they are free to come and share whatever challenges they are going through," Reverend Akoai said.

" As Melanesians, wherever we go we bring faith, community and culture with us. "

Keith Joseph says priests and brothers from Pacific Islands make up half his full-time workforce. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Christianity mixed with Indigenous beliefs

Reverend Dr Seforosa Carroll, a theologian at Charles Sturt University, said more than 90 per cent of the population in the Pacific was Christian, making religion inseparable from culture.

"To not have the church, to not have spirituality, is to lose your soul," she said.

Seforosa Carroll says, historically, becoming Christian in the Pacific required becoming "civilised" — or Westernised. (Supplied: Seferosa Carroll)

Christianity was tied to colonisation because becoming Christian often required becoming "civilised", which equated to being "Westernised", she said.

"In some cases the Christian mission and colonisation accompanied each other, and the missionary was the chief promoter of civilisation," Dr Carroll said.

Theological anthropologist at the University of Divinity's Whitley College, Reverend Dr Titus Olorunnisola, said one reason why Christianity remained popular outside the West was because of the prevalence of existential threats like poverty and political unrest.

"The only hope that people have is to hold on to their faith as a source of strength, hope and refuge," Dr Olorunnisola said.

Titus Olorunnisola says the "spiritual temperature" in Australian churches is rising. (Supplied: Titus Olorunnisola)

Another reason why Christianity was strongly embedded in some Pacific and African cultures was because people still held Indigenous beliefs of evil spirits and demons.

"The way to be spiritually protected for most people was to be a practising believer," Dr Olorunnisola said.

Huge parish demographic changes

It is an ironic pattern playing out across regional Australia — where religious leaders are now recruited from countries that were once converted by Christian missionaries from the West.

Methodist missionaries brought Christianity to Fiji in the 19th century. (Supplied: Matt Tomlinson)

When Monsignor Glynn Murphy was ordained in 1983 he remembered there being about 100 active priests across 52 parishes in the Ballarat Catholic Diocese in western Victoria.

Since then, the diocese has amalgamated its parishes so just 23 remain with about 30 priests including those from the Philippines, Vietnam and India.

Monsignor Murphy leads the Wimmera-Mallee parish and has observed congregations of migrant groups change.

Growing up in Swan Hill he saw Australians and then Italian, Dutch and Chinese families flock to mass on Sunday mornings.

He said nowadays migrants were mostly young families from the Philippines and India who came to regional Victoria to fulfil labour shortages in education, aged care and healthcare.

The congregation at St Michael and John's Catholic church is made up of many young families from the Philippines and India. (Supplied: Wimmera Filipino-Australian Club)

"They tend to have their faith and spiritual life very much to the fore … and you see that reflected in their parish attendance and presence," Monsignor Murphy said.

Assimilating through the church

One of Monsignor Murphy's parishioners is early childhood educator May Falcatan-Rosello.

She remembered hearing the Horsham church congregation sing The Lord's Prayer, a universal Christian prayer, in Tagalog after she introduced it during a mass.

Tagalog is one of the main languages in the Philippines.

"It was so real! I have goosebumps until now," she said.

Another Filipino parishioner cried because she felt like she was transported back home, she said.

Ms Falcatan-Rosello and her family are part of the Wimmera Filipino-Australian Club and attend mass every Sunday at St Michael and John's Catholic Church.

May Falcatan-Rosello and her family chose to settle in Horsham when the Catholic church embraced them. (Supplied: Wimmera Filipino-Australian Club)

Besides helping with the choir where she has introduced some Filipino hymns, she also runs morning tea and is the only reader of mass of a non-Anglo background.

"I know I have an accent, but they still roster me for it," she said.

After living in Toowoomba, Melbourne and Bendigo, Ms Falcatan-Rosello settled in Horsham because of the Catholic church and "robust Filipino community".

The Philippines is the top-ranked birthplace for Australia's overseas-born Catholics. (ABC News: Mitchell Woolnough)

In 30 years the number of Filipino-born Catholics in Australia has trebled — from less than 62,000 in 1991 to 216,000 in 2021.

It makes the Philippines the top-ranked birthplace for Australia's overseas-born Catholics.

Nearly 80 per cent of the Philippines' population identify as Catholic, which stems from Spanish colonisation that spanned more than 300 years.

Ms Falcatan-Rosello said finding a church where she could practise her faith was a consideration when choosing where to migrate to because churches provided a "sense of belonging".

"You eventually develop a support system. Sisters and brothers in faith become that for you too," she said.

Reverend Akoai's son participates in the Melanesian mass wearing his kabilato, traditional dress and ornaments from Solomon Islands. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Dr Olorunnisola said besides being part of one's identity, the church served as a "nest" that migrants could "settle into" to help them understand Australia and its colloquialisms.

"There are so many cultural assumptions that you might be coming with when you're coming from overseas," he said.

A different kind of worship

Compared to Australia, the way Christianity is practised overseas was more spiritual and overt, Dr Olorunnisola said.

People lifted their hands and sometimes each other up, and sharing spiritual experiences with others outside mass was more common.

The monthly Melanesian mass begins with a procession of parishioners wearing their traditional dress called the kabilato. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Worship in these cultures tend to be more passionate, exuberant, and deeply emotional experiences than in Australian church culture.

"Here there is so much emphasis on individualism a lot of people tend to keep their faith to themselves," Dr Olorunnisola said.

"Someone who is from a Western background within the same churches may feel 'yeah, I think the things that the pastor spoke about today were reasonable'.

"But for someone who has come from Asia … their perception of the service was 'oh, I just felt within me that God was touching people'. So you can see the dynamics."

As churches became more multicultural, Dr Olorunnisola felt the "spiritual temperature" and vibrancy was rising as people were more exposed to, and accepting, of other expressions of worship.

Melanesian parishioners carry this boat carving to the service to honour the missionaries who brought Christianity to the Pacific. (ABC News: Lucy Cooper)

Back in north Queensland, Reverend Akoai is grateful for the parish and its locals who have welcomed their Melanesian expression of faith and musicality.

"They feel like they're being nourished by the singing and dancing way of worship that we bring with us," he said.

title: The Wallabies have stalled two years out from World Cup — where to from here?
text:
The Wallabies class of 2025 has discovered three months is a long time in international rugby.

In August, the Wallabies were riding a wave of confidence and public goodwill after producing a 38-22 upset victory over world champion South Africa at Johannesburg's Ellis Park.

It was the Wallabies's first win against the Springboks at the imposing venue since 1963.

Adding to the magnitude of the achievement was the remarkable fightback they launched from 22-0 down on the scoreboard to stun not just the Springboks, but the typically parochial crowd in attendance.

While the victory shouldn't be compared to World Cup triumphs of 1991 and 1999, nor the Grand Slam in 1984 and the Bledisloe Cup series win two years later, it deserved to go down in Wallabies folklore.

The Wallabies had reason to celebrate their win over the Springboks in August. (Getty Images: Sydney Seshibedi)

Amid suggestions Australian rugby had turned the corner, however, the positive vibes didn't last for long.

The Wallabies lost eight of their next 10 Tests, including four on the trot during their spring tour, which wrapped up on Sunday morning AEDT with a 48-33 defeat to France.

The 2025 season will go down as the first in which the Wallabies lost 10 Tests in a calendar year, while not since 1958 have they gone winless on a European tour consisting of at least four internationals.

Wallabies reach historic lows The Wallabies lose a 10th Test in a calendar year for the first time, as France proves too strong in Saint-Denis.

It would be easy to ask where it went wrong, but such a question ignores the fact the warning signs have been present since Joe Schmidt took over as coach in 2024.

The loss to France illustrated some of the deficiencies in the Wallabies's game under Schmidt.

Although the tourists showed admirable spirit to play through to full-time, they failed to produce an 80-minute effort, with lapses of concentration costing them possession and territory at crucial moments during the match.

Several entries inside the French 22 were squandered, while poor discipline again contributed to their downfall.

After conceding only three penalties in the first half, the Wallabies coughed up 13 by the time the final whistle was blown, with a yellow card (Tom Hooper) also featuring on their rap sheet.

Depth in world-class talent is another issue, as Schmidt highlighted after last weekend's 46-19 defeat to Ireland in Dublin.

Max Jorgensen's brilliant second-half try showed his skill is the equal of star French winger Louis Bielle-Biarrey, and Fraser McReight proved once more he is among the best openside flankers in international rugby.

But the Wallabies were found wanting in certain positional match-ups and their options at fly half remain a genuine concern.

The number 10 jersey has been swapped around throughout the year, with Tane Edmed given the playmaker role against France after Carter Gordon's late withdrawal due to injury.

Edmed is yet to mount a case he's a Test-standard fly half, although it's hoped his move to the ACT Brumbies — where he will be coached by Steve Larkham — will accelerate his development.

Tane Edmed has struggled to make his presence felt at the Test level. (Getty Images: Franco Arland)

It's pleasing to see Gordon back in rugby after his brief stint in the NRL, but the jury is out on whether he's the answer to the Wallabies's prayers.

Gordon will need more time to re-familiarise himself with the nuances of playing fly half and next year's Super Rugby Pacific season with the Queensland Reds will be vital to this process.

Tom Lynagh, Ben Donaldson, Noah Lolesio and possibly James O'Connor are set to be the other contenders to play 10 in the build-up to the 2027 World Cup, which will be hosted by Australia.

The tournament's history has shown how challenging it is to lift the Webb Ellis Cup without a world-class fly half.

Wallabies must stick with Schmidt

The buck stops with Schmidt when it comes to the Wallabies's performances and he needs to take the lion's share of responsibility for their results.

But sacking the New Zealander would be the wrong call.

Schmidt — whose winning record with the Wallabies sits below 40 per cent — is due to hand over the reins to Reds coach Les Kiss following the Wallabies's Nations Championship Tests next July.

This arrangement was announced last April and needs to go through as planned.

Joe Schmidt is set to remain Wallabies coach until mid-next year. (Getty Images: Timothy Rogers)

Removing Schmidt from his post has the potential to cause instability inside the Wallabies program, just as it did when Dave Rennie was sacked at the beginning of 2023.

And moving Kiss into the role earlier than scheduled would disrupt the Reds's Super Rugby Pacific campaign.

Australia's four Super Rugby Pacific franchises can't afford to be compromised in any way if they are to contend for the championship.

Rugby Australia has publicly indicated they have no plans to move Schmidt on early. The governing body must stick firm to this approach.

This is despite the drums beating louder among sections of the media, as well as members of the Wallabies's loyal — but long-suffering — supporter base.

title: Make a Christmas wreath with flowers from your garden
text:
In Australia, Christmas wreaths have typically been structured around European accoutrements, but did you know it is easy to make a wreath with produce from your own garden?

Australians who want to add their own Christmas flair are embracing native flower wreaths, according to Candice Burger, a flower farmer at Bowral, in the southern highlands of NSW.

"We've moved a long way from the traditional European wreath, with holly and berries and pine," Ms Burger said.

"We're really slowly crossing a new frontier with Australian native wreaths taking shape here."

Billy buttons are a native Australian flower. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Ms Burger said native plants worked well in wreaths with other garden flowers.

"If you take dried hydrangeas and put yellow billy button balls with them, then add any green foliage, you know, you've got the green and the gold," she said.

"Billy buttons grow beautifully in Australia, they're native and add pops of colour. The stems are quite rigid so threading them one at a time is easier.

"Then you could add in banksia, which is red for Christmas.

"I think Australians are definitely putting their own take on the wreath and a lot of wreaths are beautiful sculptures."

Candice Burger grows vines to harvest for wreath bases. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Garden inspiration

The wreath base is generally a circle constructed from plaited or twisted wood, which can be branches or vines from around your home.

"Use an ornamental grapevine or even wisteria," Ms Burger said.

"Then using jute or copper wire, bend them into any shape you want and find a dry place to hang it."

The base holds the wreath together and makes construction easy. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Making a wreath requires few tools but secateurs, wire, jute, a wreath base, floral ingredients and ribbon are a minimum.

"Use sharp secateurs for cutting stems, leaves and wire and have both thick and thin wire on hand to hold items in place," Ms Burger said.

"Using twine makes your wreath compostable."

Vines are twisted into circles and then tied off with twine. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Tips for making a wreath

Ms Burger said you should prepare to make a big mess that you can clean up later, and to just have fun and go crazy with it.

"Prepare by stripping leaves and securing flowers as a group, cut wire lengths long enough to twist tightly at the back of the wreath," she said.

"Wreaths can get heavy so prepare a lot of wire or twine to secure it."

A combination of dried and fresh flowers is perfect for inserting into wreaths. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

She suggests mixing dry and fresh ingredients, bunching and overlapping it together including fresh banksias, leaves, branches, pine cones, rosemary and lavender.

"To add textured coloured elements, mix the ingredients with dry and fresh produce, which will dry on the wreath.

"We've also made wreaths with fresh cut paper daisies, pine and lavender, even fresh hydrangeas dry on the wreath, so you can just go into your garden and cut what's there."

Candice Burger starts making a wreath with bunches of flowers. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Adding layers

Ms Burger said there were no rules while constructing your wreath.

"Let ingredients flop outside the circle, create texture by overlapping your ingredients, fill gaps and during construction hold the wreath any which way, it's a work in progress, so don't be shy.

"It's easy to work with one ingredient at a time and just keep adding and layering up.

Creating a Christmas wreath is an exercise in imagination. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

"Hard petals, like a paper daisy, work well but there are flowering shrubs and trees that have interesting seed pods, and you can include those.

"If you've got a fruiting tree like an ornamental cherry, that's fun to do, so is dehydrating fruit," she said.

Tips include following the circle base and looking for spaces in the wood from behind.

Hold the stems tightly, and using the wire, wind them around the wreath.

"Don't worry, you can keep adding to the wreath or finish quite minimally, there are no rules," Ms Burger said.

Finishing off

Add ribbons to your wreath for pops of colour and texture. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Ms Burger suggests waiting until you have finished to tidy up the back, add bows and ribbons and test it in place.

"Use beautiful vintage ribbon, wind that in and make it your own personality," she said.

"Wind stems into place so they're not sticking out, you don't want to see them; then twist the wire to finish it off.

"Don't secure strands and cut until you know you've finished," she said.

Alternately, you don't need to cut the wire off, you can just go around keeping the tension quite tight.

Candice Burger with a Christmas wreath she made. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

"Then hang it and step back from it, don't be shy to move things about," Ms Burger said.

"There's so many things you can find in your garden, you can prep all year for it, or you can go out that day and harvest from your garden.

"You'll be surprised by how beautiful you can make a wreath."

Candice Burger recommends using fresh and dried flowers in Christmas wreaths. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

title: Live: Piastri hoping to hit the jackpot in Vegas with F1 title hopes at stake
text:
Oscar Piastri's Formula 1 title hopes could be critically damaged in Las Vegas, as the Australian starts fifth on the grid, with championship leader Lando Norris on pole.

Piastri enters Sunday's grand prix with a 24-point deficit to Norris, having not finished ahead of his teammate in any race since August.

Follow all the action of the Formula 1 Las Vegas Grand Prix on the live blog below.

Key Events Lando Norris on pole after a terrific qualifying session 8 minutes ago STARTING GRID: F1 Las Vegas Grand Prix 15 minutes ago What time does the F1 Las Vegas Grand Prix start? 19 minutes ago Show all key events Lando Norris on pole after a terrific qualifying session M By Michael Doyle Lando Norris was simply brilliant in wet conditions yesterday. He stormed to pole position with a breathtaking performance. Oscar Piastri could not nail his final lap, and will start today's grand prix from fifth. Catch up on yesterday's action by tapping the link below. Piastri to start fifth in Las Vegas as Norris claims pole STARTING GRID: F1 Las Vegas Grand Prix M By Michael Doyle What time does the F1 Las Vegas Grand Prix start? M By Michael Doyle Here is when the race will begin in each of Australia's states and territories: 3pm AEDT: NSW, ACT, Vic, Tas

2:30pm ACDT: South Australia

2pm AEST: Queensland

1:30pm ACST: Northern Territory

12pm AWST: Western Australia Welcome to the ABC Sport live blog M By Michael Doyle Hello Australia. Welcome back to ABC Sport's live digital coverage of the 2025 Formula 1 championship season. This afternoon, Formula 1 races on the famous Las Vegas Strip. This is round 22 of 24, with races in Qatar and Abu Dhabi to end the season. Australian Oscar Piastri is second in the drivers' championship, 24 points adrift of his teammate Lando Norris. Join the conversation, and let us know your thoughts on all things F1, in the comment section.

title: Woman's near miss with ceiling collapse as storm causes severe damage at Port Pirie
text:
Thousands of residents are facing outages in the South Australian town of Port Pirie after a severe thunderstorm and hail destroyed roofs as well as bringing down trees and powerlines.

The State Emergency Services (SES) said they received 170 calls for help in a 12-hour period after wind gusts of 119 kilometres per hour were recorded in the town after 8pm on Saturday night.

SA Power Networks external affairs manager Cecilia Schutz told ABC Radio Adelaide a strong and short storm cell caused significant damage, bringing down up to 50 power lines in and around Port Pirie.

"The combination of a lot of damage and difficulty accessing sites is going to mean that customers in Port Pirie are likely to have an extended outage, I would expect that most of the customers who are out are going to be out beyond today," Ms Schutz said.

Large trees brought down power lines at Port Pirie on Saturday. (Supplied: SA Power Networks)

Port Pirie resident Angela Lewis said her ceiling almost fell on her when she went to inspect the damage overnight.

"My hubby went out with a torch because all the power went out and he could hear water running and he looked up … and it was coming through the ceiling all round the light fittings," Ms Lewis said.

"We went out and we saw all in our back room was in ankle deep water.

"I was still trying to take some photos, luckily I took a step back to get a long shot and the ceiling collapsed so it just missed me. It missed me by about a foot."

Water leaked through Angela Lewis's home after a severe storm. (Supplied: Angela Lewis)

Ms Lewis said her kitchen, dining room, an entertaining room and a shed were destroyed in the storm, which happened within "10, 15 minutes".

"All the back section of our house is unusable," she said.

"The wind was that hard it took the paint off my outdoor setting … we went out this morning to check the damage we had white flecks everywhere."

Angela Lewis says her shed was also destroyed in the storm. (Supplied: Angela Lewis)

She said the damage was extensive around Port Pirie.

"Emergency services have closed off the street because there's trees down in our street," she said.

"The hail was unbelievable … my husband walking into it, it was up to his ankles."

Hail reported around Port Pirie during a severe thunderstorm on Saturday night. (Supplied: Michelle Waters)

SES state duty officer Ian Bonython said they had requested support from their metropolitan volunteers as well as from the Country and Metropolitan Fire Services as the calls for assistance overnight poured in.

"The warning from the Bureau of Meteorology did say it was going to be strong winds and damaging winds so we were expecting it, but not as heavy and not as many taskings as what we did receive," Mr Bonython said.

"The majority of the taskings we attended to last night were wind-related so loose roofing, tree branches and the SA Power Networks were attending to powerlines down.

"We also had water-related tasks where water was entering through the ceilings and rising up in people's back and front yards."

Port Pirie residents experienced hail during a severe storm on Saturday night. (Supplied: Shamus Hawthorn)

Bureau of Meteorology meteorologist Jenny Horvat said thunderstorms moved from west to east across South Australia on Saturday but temperatures across the state would warm up on Sunday.

"We did also see some severe thunderstorms around the Port Pirie area last night," Ms Horvat said.

"It is spring, we do expect to see these dynamic troughs and lows moving across the state at this time of year."

She said the heaviest rainfall was around the Adelaide metropolitan area, receiving about 20 to 40 millimetres overnight.

"West Terrace picked up 25mm of rain — that's been our wettest day since July here in the city, and for November we haven't seen rainfall in that range for a couple of years there."

title: Treasury should take on Australia's oligopolies, new think tank says
text:
It's time to beef up the Department of Treasury in Canberra.

A new public policy think tank has called for Treasury to become the driving force behind a new national program to reinvigorate Australia's economy.

Policy Institute Australia (PIA) says Australia desperately needs a shot of micro-economic reform to reinvigorate competition and unleash a wave of productivity growth.

PM won't force break up of supermarket duopoly Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says Coles and Woolworths "clearly have excessive market power", but he rejects any suggestion of introducing divestiture powers.

It says it's time to replicate the National Competition Policy program that began in 1995, in response to the Hilmer Report in 1993, which catalysed Australia's subsequent productivity boom.

"A serious bout of pro-competition reform helped launch Australia out of its economic malaise in the 1970s and 1980s when the government launched the National Competition Policy (NCP) in 1995," it says.

"Though the Hilmer reforms are often thought of as "big bang," in fact the reform process took 10 years.

"Policy Institute Australia believes a commitment of $20 billion in funding over a 10-year reform period ($2 billion per annum) would be consistent with the commitment to the 1995 NCP effort," it says.

What is Policy Institute Australia?

Policy Institute Australia (PIA) is a new think tank.

It was established earlier this year with seed funding from investment banker John Wylie and his wife, Myriam Boisbouvier-Wylie.

Competition watchdog to get a boost in powers Australia's competition watchdog, the ACCC, will be given far stronger powers to prevent companies making repeated under-the-radar acquisitions that could harm competition and consumers.

It released its first report last week.

PIA says it wants to bring fresh ideas about how to address Australia's big economic challenges, using market-based solutions where appropriate, while recognising the role governments play in market economies.

Its board members include John Wylie, Professor Glyn Davis, former Productivity Commission chair Peter Harris, News Corp Australia journalist Paul Kelly, Jenn Morris, and former ABC news director Kate Torney.

"We believe in the long-term benefits of capitalism, free enterprise and a well-functioning market economy," its website says. "We recognise that capitalism can and does overshoot on occasion, and can lag in its ability to appropriately and fairly manage externalities and systemic risk. "We believe that there is an important role for governments in regulating markets that can and should occur, without unnecessarily impeding economic growth and investment. "We believe there can be a role for government investment or intervention in markets to help create new industries, address market failure, or crowd in private sector investment – but that government investment should not be a first or default option."

PIA says this is the first report in a planned series.

After identifying the reasons for the lack of competition in major areas of Australia's economy, and the causes of our poor productivity performance, it plans to use forthcoming papers to suggest solutions for big problems.

It says Australia enjoyed a burst of productivity growth in the late 1990s and early 2000s during the era of National Competition Policy.

But in the 20 years since, Australia's economy has again become riddled with issues with declining competition and deteriorating productivity.

It says key indicators show what that means.

Industry concentration worsens

First, industry concentration has been increasing in Australia in the 21st century.

In banking, supermarkets, private health insurance and iron ore mining, the top four players control between 70 per cent and 90 per cent of the market.

It says the average market share of the top four firms across all industries in the economy has increased from about 41 per cent in 2001-02 to about 43 per cent in 2018-19.

The four major banks together hold about 72 per cent of banking system assets.

In private health, Medibank and Bupa, HCF, nib and HBF hold 82 per cent of the market, with Medibank and Bupa accounting for more than half.

In general insurance, IAG, Suncorp, Allianz and QBE control around three quarters of the home and motor insurance market.

In the retail energy market, AGL, Origin and EnergyAustralia serve 60 per cent of electricity customers and about 80 per cent of gas customers.

Fewer new firms, older firms sticking around

Second, it says Australia has seen a falling rate of firm entry and exit in the 21st century.

It says the entry of new firms into the economy, and the exit of failing firms, is a key marker of dynamism. That's because new firms bring new ideas and new energy, and lessons learned from business failures can sprout future success.

But with fewer challengers starting up and fewer under-performers exiting, incumbent firms are likely to stay at the top.

Labour mobility keeps declining

Third, it says labour mobility has been declining for 40 years.

"More competing firms means more options for workers about where to work," the report says.

"How often workers choose to switch jobs can therefore reflect how much competition there is across the economy.

"In Australia, more and more workers have been choosing to stay in their current job, rather than find a new one, with labour mobility declining over more than four decades."

The bottom line — competition is on the decline

Overall, it says measuring competition is tricky, but the pattern in the available evidence is consistent.

The holiday is over If Australia is to keep growing national income as the terms of trade decline it needs a big increase in both infrastructure and operational capital investment.

"Across 12 indicators that are commonly used as proxy measures for competitive conditions, all the metrics show that Australian competition is on the decline," it says.

"The pace of change is not dramatic, but it seems persistent.

"If this decline continues, the risk rises that Australians will miss out on the benefits of competition — higher productivity, greater affordability, more choice of what to buy or where to work, high-quality products, and more innovation," it says.

The ultimate performance metric

It says the most direct measure of poor competition in an industry relates to pricing power, which is measured by tracking "markups".

And the evidence of markups is going the wrong way.

"A markup is the difference between the sale price of a product and how much it cost for the firm to produce or acquire that product," PIA's report says. "It is literally a ‘mark up’ — the amount a firm adds on top of cost to set the final price."

It says a paper released by Treasury in 2023 found that, on average, firms had increased their markups by about 5 per cent between 2003 and 2017, suggesting that competition across the economy had weakened over that period.

How electricity became a political weapon A decade and a half after an energy company CEO outlined his greatest fears for Australia's economic future — no carbon price — the nation again appears set for a renewed battle over climate policy and power generation.

It says Treasury followed that up with another paper in August, which estimated the economic impact of that fall in competition.

It asked the question: if the economy had the same level of competition in 2017 as it did in 2003 (measured by markups and other measures), what would productivity growth have been?

"The authors found that if the economy had retained the level of competition in 2017 as it had in 2003, productivity growth would have been up to 3 per cent higher, worth about $3,000 per Australian," it says.

How to break the impasse

What to do about it?

PIA says Australia has become far too reliant on the competition regulator to try to manage the problem of deteriorating competition, and the ACCC can't grow a more competitive Australia on its own.

It says we need to break the policy impasse.

"The Commonwealth should empower Treasury as the national steward of pro-competition policy reform, building on the Competition Taskforce, including a mandate and resources to design and implement a bold pro-competition reform agenda over a 10-year time frame," it argues. "In public policy, we have become heavily reliant on the competition regulator, the ACCC, on all matters to do with competition. "But the ACCC’s mandate is to slow or stop the substantial lessening of competition, not to proactively identify problematic sectors where competition has declined and advance solutions to encourage more competition. "The ACCC alone cannot grow a more competitive Australia. "We need a leader of action in policy to drive increased competition, or coordinate where necessary, to spark productivity and better outcomes for all Australians. "This should be Treasury," it says.

It says to support a revitalised role for Treasury, we need to uplift the current National Competition Policy in scope and effort, creating "National Competition Policy 2.0".

And that should include a specific focus on how to remove from industry incumbents the power to set rules that determine who can compete with them, or impose unnecessary costs to impede competition.

"In its last term, the Commonwealth government led the states and territories in laying the foundations for a revitalised NCP," it said.

"Since the government’s 2025 re-election, it has laid out the case and its own ambition to lead a much-needed program of reform to boost Australia’s economic performance.

"Now is the time for action," it says.

title: Two-day Ashes Test could cost Cricket Australia millions
text:
Just weeks after forecasting a record year ahead, Cricket Australia (CA) is facing a multi-million-dollar drain after the rapid-fire two-day Ashes opener.

A combination of Travis Head's all-time Ashes knock and Bazball's cavalier approach to batting led to the first game of the blockbuster series in Perth ending late on day two.

CA is headed for an estimated loss of more than $3 million from ticket revenue for days three and four.

A record 101,514 attended the Test — 51,531 on Friday, then 49,983 — to surpass the record set of 96,463 in Perth last year when India won in four days.

Day three was also almost sold out.

Speaking before play on Saturday, when Australia's first innings hadn't even finished, CA chief executive Todd Green half-joked he was worried about the Test not making it to day three.

"It's difficult for a number of different groups," Greenberg told SEN when discussing the financial impact of a match finishing early.

"Our broadcasters first of all.

"Certainly us, on ticket sales and our partners and sponsors.

"There's a big economic impact on this series."

Thousands of England fans had bought tickets for the third day of the first Ashes Test in Perth. (AAP: Dave Hunt)

At the annual general meeting last month, CA announced a loss of $11.3 million and took strong criticism from Cricket Victoria chair Ross Hepburn for the financial performance.

CA defends $11.3m loss Cricket Australia insists record numbers are ahead despite facing criticism after losing more than $11 million in a summer that included a five-Test home series against India.

The loss took in a summer that included a five-Test tour from goliath India.

"In a normal scheduling, you'd have the white-ball cricket as part of that [Test] tour, but that's being played in this financial year," CA chair Mike Baird said after the meeting in October.

"If they were in the same financial year, you would have seen a different position.

"We're in a position where it's a significant uplift, an over-$20 million improvement.

Loading...

"Hang on to your hats because next year we are going to have a record year in cricket.

"You're going to see the most attendance, the most viewership, the most sponsorship."

Foxtel said their broadcast on Friday was the most-watched first day of a first Test in its history

The Seven Network also reported strong ratings for coverage on day one.

AAP

title: Pelvic pain devastates lives amid vast research gaps
text:
Jaali Barton was working her dream job running snorkelling tours at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, when sudden debilitating pelvic pain left her curled up on the beach, unable to walk.

Bouts of pain had become more and more frequent for Ms Barton over the past decade, beginning at age 14.

"It is the worst pain you can imagine," she said.

"It feels like your insides are being carved out with a knife. It feels like everything is just exploding inside you."

Ms Barton was forced to come home to mainland Australia to seek treatment, but even that has proved difficult.

Shortfalls in funding and focus on the condition have left women like Ms Barton in prolonged pain, according to advocates.

Jaali Barton says her chronic pelvic pain forced her to leave her dream job as a tour guide on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. (Supplied: Jaali Barton)

Untreatable pain

Two years on, the 24-year-old remains at home with her parents in the small coastal town of Kalbarri in Western Australia.

Her pain has only worsened.

Ms Barton loves days at the beach, travelling, doing yoga, working at her job as an education assistant and catching up with friends.

But her pelvic pain now flares almost every day and can last from hours to several days, trapping her inside her bedroom.

The walls are lined with beach photos and shells, but it remains a world apart from the life she misses.

"It's taken so much from me. All the things that I find joy in are now really difficult," Ms Barton explained.

Ms Barton's pain affects her pelvis and shoots down her legs, and is often coupled with head pain and fatigue.

Jaali Barton says it is hard to make plans when your body is unpredictable. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Brianna Melville)

She said it could not be eased by painkillers.

Ms Barton said her symptoms had caused her to frequently miss work, cancel plans with friends and give up travelling and exercise.

As a result, Ms Barton said it is extremely difficult to feel positive about her future.

"You just think, 'what's a life of being in pain every day,'" she said.

"It's living day by day, making no plans because your body is just unpredictable.

Jaali Barton says she feels alone in the fight with her own body. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Brianna Melville)

Long road to diagnosis

Ms Barton said that over the years that she has had symptoms, her mum would drive her the two hours to the Geraldton emergency department as often as twice a month.

However, once appendicitis was ruled out, she says doctors were left unsure about how to treat her.

“Most doctors, nurses, no one actually knows anything about it,” she said.

“You’re kind of left in the dark, on your own.”

After 10 years of seeking help, Ms Barton finally had a diagnostic surgery earlier this year, with a biopsy taken of an internal lesion.

The biopsy pointed to endosalpingiosis, but other doctors have speculated that she also has endometriosis.

Jaali Barton in hospital. (Supplied: Jaali Barton)

Both conditions involve reproductive organ tissue growing outside of where it belongs, often causing pain and inflammation.

She says she joined an eight-month wait-list for an appointment with a specialist to discuss the results of her surgery.

However, worsening pain now has her fearing that the lesions are spreading, and she persistently calls asking for her appointment to be moved forward.

She said enlisting the help of a naturopath and a pelvic physio has provided her some comfort this year, alongside a community of women she has connected with online.

“I get so many messages from young girls thinking they have the same thing, they have endo, they have the same symptoms," she said.

“If sharing this story is going to help anyone, then that’s going to help me.”

Research gaps remain

The founder and chair of the Pelvic Pain Foundation of Australia, Susan Evans, says while patients with pelvic pain often expect to be "fixed" by doctors, major shortfalls in research have limited what they can do.

Susan Evans is a gynaecologist, laparoscopic surgeon and pain physician who has authored a book about endometriosis and pelvic pain. (Supplied: Dr Susan Evans)

“There has been so little research in this space for generations," Dr Evans said.

“A lot of the data that we expect to be available just isn’t available.”

As a result, Dr Evans says “a lot of catch-up” is required in research to fully understand the prevalence of pelvic pain and investigate its causes, which will require serious funding.

However, she says it is important for people with pelvic pain to learn about it themselves and build a team of health professionals to address their specific needs.

title: 'Albo's Greatest Hits' as PM's western vacation yields little for WA
text:
When the prime minister and his entourage rolled into town on Monday, Premier Roger Cook might have been hoping Anthony Albanese had packed him an early Christmas present.

The PM's visit had all the hallmarks of the kind of obligatory trips made all across the country this time of year.

Whether they liked it or not, Anthony Albanese loaded his kids (ministers) into the car for a journey west to visit some distant relatives (their WA counterparts).

There was time for holiday happy snaps along the Busselton foreshore, dinner at a nearby brewery and a morning coffee in Bunbury.

Loading Instagram content

But the prime minister didn't have anything on Cook's wish list to give him.

Instead, it was two days of 'Albo's Greatest Hits' on replay as the PM made few announcements but found some good news to stand in front of.

Health concerns

At the top of the wish list for Cook this Christmas, and for every other state and territory leader, is more money for health.

Hospitals across the country are struggling to keep up with plenty of pressures. It is up to the states and territories, who run public hospitals, to manage that, with help from federal funds.

States demand hospitals come before federal bottom line State and territory leaders hold an emergency meeting over public hospital funding, declaring they cannot sacrifice hospital care to bolster the Commonwealth's finances.

Albanese had promised to help states and territories increase the Commonwealth's share of that funding two years ago, but negotiations have stalled.

He told them in September to rein in spending, saying the Commonwealth was happy to increase its share, but with a cap on the total growth in its contribution.

"States cannot cut public hospital activity to suit the federal government's bottom line," was the response from Tasmanian Premier, on behalf of his counterparts, on Wednesday.

They argue the reason they're increasing hospital spending is because the Commonwealth has dropped the ball in areas like aged care and bulk billing.

"We've already seen the Albanese Labor government provide significant support for urgent care clinics which takes pressure off the hospitals, so I want to give them a bouquet in relation to that," Cook said in August.

"But I'll also give them a brick. They need to do better on aged care."

Despite missing out on extra money, or even a hat for joining the Prime Minister aboard the USS Vermont on Wednesday, there was no "brick" for the PM when he was standing behind Cook on Wednesday.

Roger Cook was noticeably hat-less when he joined the prime minister aboard the USS Vermont on Wednesday. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

But Cook rejected the suggestion he'd lost his nerve.

"Not at all … we'll continue to make sure that we work with the Commonwealth to improve the full range of care opportunities across people's life journey," he told reporters.

"Those conversations are ongoing. I met with my fellow premiers today. We are continuing to push forward with that conversation."

For his part, Albanese did not seem to be in any great rush to get the deal done before the end of the year, saying: "We'll wait and see".

"So the states have a big incentive on engaging constructively, because otherwise it rolls over for another year."

Reinforcing achievements

When people (especially those who you want to vote for you) can't get the care they need though, they usually don't care about the complexities of federal-state relations — they just want it fixed.

Luckily for both Cook and Albanese, having been resoundingly re-elected this year, they've got some time to rebuild goodwill with voters in other areas.

That's probably part of the reason Albanese's two major media events were about two major achievements.

On Tuesday, he visited the future site of a gallium processing plant.

Central to a $13 billion critical minerals deal he struck with US President Donald Trump last month, it could help diversify WA's iron-ore reliant mining industry.

Anthony Albanese says the gallium project is happening "right here, right now". (ABC News: Pip Waller)

The following morning, he was on Garden Island to meet Australian submariners and defence contractors helping maintain a US submarine.

It's the same type of sub Australia is expecting to get at least three of, as soon as the early 2030s under the AUKUS defence pact with the United States and United Kingdom.

This round of maintenance is a big deal because it's the first time this level of support has been provided to a US submarine outside of a US base.

Unresolved issues

But even those wins come with some unresolved issues for a prime minister still buoyed by his election win in May.

And among the myriad of risks that come with AUKUS — including concerns over whether it will even happen — locals who stand to benefit from it aren't all sold just yet.

Businesses urge parties to 'work together' The next few days are viewed as critical to landing a deal on the proposed reforms to update the EPBC Act, amid hopes the Liberals will be more motivated to bolster their environmental credentials after ditching net zero.

There are still lingering concerns about there being enough houses nearby, and the ability for already congested roads to keep up with an influx of submariners and workers.

Also of concern is whether the federal government will be able to pass its latest attempt at overhauling the nation's environment laws, with neither the Greens nor Coalition pledging their support just yet.

Both government and industry want to get those changes through, sooner rather than later, to help speed up approvals for critical minerals and renewables projects.

Cook helped sink the last attempt at rewriting the laws. He almost certainly won't keep quiet if the new version stops him getting Christmas cards from the state's mining industry leaders.

He's only got one sitting week left to worry about — then it might be up to him to offer a present to West Australians when the government hands down its budget update before Christmas.

Loading...

title: Svarc plug: Ruby dazzles as Lions' blitz ends Blues
text:
Ruby Svarc has dazzled with a career-best haul as the Brisbane Lions hit top gear to trounce Carlton and set up a third-straight AFLW grand-final clash with North Melbourne.

Svarc, who had just 17 goals in her previous 55 games, slotted four to power a third-quarter blitz in Saturday night's 10.7 (67) to 5.2 (32) victory in front of 6,511 fans in Brisbane.

The hosts kicked five goals in 11 minutes to break the contest open after half-time, with Dakota Davidson adding a highlight reel effort from the pocket in a thrilling six-goal third term.

"They were awesome … haven't had many six-goal quarters in our history and it was on the back of the dam wall bursting … it was a matter of time," Lions coach Craig Starcevich said.

He said you could have "named your odds" of Svarc kicking four goals in a preliminary final when she arrived at the club as a rough, athletic diamond.

Loading Instagram content

"No [I didn't expect it] is the short answer, although that's a bit harsh on Ruby because she's one of the hardest workers," he said.

"She's slowly, slowly got better and better … that was amazing."

Brisbane's ninth-straight win, after a week of spicy back-and-forth banter between the sides, reversed the result of their round-three meeting.

It will be the two-time premiers' fourth-straight grand final appearance and seventh in 10 seasons.

And it ensured the Lions and Kangaroos, on a 26-game unbeaten run, will meet again in a third-straight decider next Saturday after the defending champions survived a scare to beat Melbourne by 10 points.

"They've got their amazing run and we're also on a bit of a run," Starcevich said.

"I'm looking forward to it because the type of footy we've been playing can challenge anyone."

The Lions hammered away in the first quarter but were sloppy and had little to show for their 12 inside-50 entries in a goalless term.

The hosts remained frantic in the second term and it was Svarc, who had never kicked more than two goals in a game, who settled to take the spoils.

First she scooped up a loose ball, raced clear of the contest and, after giving and receiving a handball, kicked a goal on the run.

Kangaroos star on being challenged North Melbourne will play in its third consecutive AFLW grand final after weathering an almighty scare from Melbourne.

Then she regathered from her own smothered shot on goal to slot a second major in quick time.

Taylor Smith soccered another through for Brisbane, before Poppy Sholz's second from a free kick made it a five-point margin at the main break.

Svarc wasn't done, a banana kick from the pocket delivering her third before she found more open space and hit Courtney Hodder on the chest.

Hodder converted for a 17-point lead and then it was party time when Dakota Davidson tapped towards the boundary and somehow finessed the tight angle for another brilliant goal.

Blues defender Harriet Cordner was pinged for a deliberate rushed behind and Ellie Hampson snuck the goal through, before Davidson's second — a clean strike from 45 metres — made it five majors in 11 minutes.

Sophie McKay dragged one back for the Blues, but the sweet-striking Hampson had the reply with the final act of an exhilarating quarter.

Svarc then completed the dream night, pouncing on a loose ball to swing through her fourth goal and all-but end the contest early in the fourth term.

Blues coach Mathew Buck said the Lions' contested work proved too tough to handle, tipping his cap to the competition's standout sides.

"We got found out a little bit tonight but overall very proud of what we achieved this year," he said.

"Two teams in there that run great programs and their coaches are hard to coach against.

"The fact they're in there [the final again] is great, fantastic for the competition … they're exactly what we want to be."

AAP

title: 'Stressful the whole game': Kangaroos star on being challenged by Dees
text:
In Saturday's first preliminary final, North Melbourne found themselves in a position they hadn't been in for a while.

The reigning premiers were down at every change against rivals Melbourne. The last time they trailed at three-quarter time was back in 2023, a game they lost to the same opposition.

Then skipper Jasmine Garner took control.

She had 12 disposals, four clearances, four score involvements and the last goal of the game, just in the final term, which helped propel North into its third consecutive grand final with a slim 10-point victory.

Yet it was a small moment from Kangaroos forward Alice O'Loughlin that caught ABC commentator Chyloe Kurdas's eye.

"[North were] under so much pressure, probably uncharacteristic for North Melbourne, but there was a moment in that fourth quarter that probably turned the game for me," Kurdas said.

North down Demons to secure grand final berth After surviving some nervous moments, North Melbourne have progressed to another grand final courtesy of a narrow prelim win over the Demons.

The Kangaroos were down by a goal when O'Loughlin was attacking the ball at the top of their inside 50.

While under pressure, she was clean in getting a small handball off to Blaithin Bogue, who kicked the first goal of the fourth quarter to spark the Kangaroos' comeback.

"That just changed the scoreboard, and it changed the momentum in the game," Kurdas said.

O'Loughlin laughed when she heard this.

"I get a bit of stick, always have to give the first gives, the first hands. Croc (North coach Darren Crocker) [is] always nailing into me on that one," she said.

"So I … straight away went to see him, and was like, 'What do you got to say now?'"

She added that it was Bogue, however, who had a good run.

"I mean, she's a great player and we're so lucky to have her," she said.

It was the Kangaroos' 26th consecutive win, a record they had to fight tooth and nail to keep alive against the Demons, who went into the game as heavy underdogs.

Jasmine Garner helped lift her side to a preliminary final win against the Demons. (Getty: Michael Willson/AFL Photos)

"Look, it was a stressful whole game, to be honest. Melbourne really brought the pressure," O'Loughlin said.

"They're such a quality outfit".

The difference, however, was in North's legs.

"Credit to our fitness staff," she said.

"We really have a lot of faith in these moments, in these tough games, that all of us can run them out to the last siren.

"So we just have confidence in that."

It is something that will come in handy now the Kangaroos are set to face Brisbane in the grand final after the Lions defeated Carlton in the second preliminary final by a comprehensive 35 points.

For the third decider in a row, the pair will battle for the flag; each side with one premiership apiece in the now trilogy.

Each side is also known for their fitness and dominance, especially for Brisbane in finals.

title: England's brainless Perth capitulation only the beginning
text:
Ben Stokes probably summed it up best.

The unflappable hero of Headingley, England's talisman and chief destroyer just 24 hours prior, admitted to being "a little bit shell-shocked" after Australia, or more specifically Travis Head, wrestled Australia out of a desperately tough spot to claim a thumping first Test victory in Perth.

Others were not so kind.

Former skipper Michael Vaughan was scathing, rubbishing England's approach with the bat that resulted in two collapses in as many days and the surrendering of a powerful position midway through day two.

"It disappoints me hugely," Vaughan told Fox Sports.

"In 2023, the first Test match at Edgbaston, England was dominating and in the second innings Nathan Lyon got five-fa [sic] with England playing some dumb cricket. Pat Cummins saw them over the line [with the bat], Australia 1-0 up.

"Then they went to Lord's … dumb cricket, get bowled out, England 2-0 down.

"Two years later, at the first time of asking, I see a batting unit playing the exactly same way.

"Five hours ago England were dominating the game. Five hours later we're sitting here, Australia are 1-0 up."

England simply could not find a way out of the mire. (Getty Images: Gareth Copley)

It's true. England was dominating, 99 runs ahead at lunch on the second day with nine wickets in hand.

The carnage of day one seemed, if not a distant memory, then at least a fever-dream that both teams had been able to put behind them — the shaking out of all those pre-Ashes nerves manifest in a ridiculous smorgasbord of accelerated gameplay.

But then, with everything seemingly in hand, a litany of atrocious shots resulted in England collapsing into an ungainly heap for the second straight innings.

The same old story, so familiar to England fans, was being written once again.

England went from 1-65 to 6-88 in 8.2 overs and were all out with a lead of just 204. In the first innings, it was a collapse of 5-12 in just 18 balls.

But Vaughan and plenty of others were aghast at the manner of the dismissals.

Scott Boland took three wickets in 11 balls after lunch. (Getty Images: Paul Kane/Cricket Australia)

"We've been saying we want 'Bazball with brains' but the brains haven't arrived," Vaughan told the BBC.

"They're all trying to whack it to the boundary, it's so disappointing. I look back to last year and it looked like they were learning. I don't see how they can win a big series batting like that.

"I thought England had a good chance but the bowlers weren't even getting a rest; 30 overs but it wasn't even 30 overs because they were padding up, it's unacceptable.

"It's silly for us to think they'll win down under if we play like that. This match, they haven't used their tools correctly."

Bazball with brains? Perhaps that's Travball.

While Head picked his moments and carved England's attack to all corners, England's shot selection was decried as "substandard" by BBC broadcasting doyen Jonathan Agnew, "really poor" by Justin Langer and "inexcusable" by Vaughan.

England's hall of shame of brainless batting was low-lighted by three of England's supposed best on Saturday in a half-hour period that sent a collection of England's ex-players apoplectic in rage.

During England's hideous second-day capitulation, Ollie Pope, Harry Brook and Joe Root all perished to near-identical shots.

Joe Root's atrocious shot was just one of many in England's collapse. (Getty Images: Philip Brown)

Pope, having been in the middle for an hour and a half and having faced 56 balls, may have felt a full-blooded drive at a ball outside off stump was vindicated. Every batting coach in history would suggest his lack of footwork was not, but perhaps there can be some accommodation to a man who had looked quite sharp.

However, for Brook to play the very same shot against the very same bowler two minutes later borders on the idiotic.

For Root, the number one-ranked Test batter in the world, to follow suit with another shot from a statuesque base, was ludicrous.

Stuart Broad, no stranger to stupid dismissals himself, could not hide a visible obscenity on Channel 7's coverage, with his reaction doubtlessly repeated and amplified in English living rooms throughout the early hours of the morning back home.

England lost those three wickets of arguably their best batters in the space of five fraught deliveries as panic cascaded down the line-up like a dousing of freezing cold water would subdue a pack of overly energetic dogs.

Yes, the batting was woeful.

But the bowlers cannot escape scrutiny for their part in the shambles that followed.

In the space of 24 hours, England's arsenal of pace bowlers went from a world-beating quintet compared to the legendary trio of pace bowlers who terrorised Australia in the late 1950s to an embarrassed collection of club cricketers being pummelled to all parts of Perth Stadium.

Never has the hammer been fashioned into the nail so swiftly.

The Barmy Army, raucously anticipating every 150km/h missile one day, were left sullen and silent as Head and Marnus Labuschagne, frankly, rendered them impotent with a blistering array of shots to all corners of the ground.

Defeats like this can leave a lasting scar on the psyche of young players. (Getty Images: Gareth Copley)

England's five-pronged attack was lethal in the first innings, averaging 141km/h on day one, the fastest data provider CricViz has recorded since it started doing so in 2006.
